Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Characterizing El Nino Runoff And Sedimentation In Small Drainage Basins: A Geoarchaeological Study

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
It is now well known by the general public that El Niños have dramatic impacts world wide yet, in many ways there is still much to learn about these events and their effects. This project will help us to better understand past El Niños so that one can better prepare for them in the future. El Niños occur when warm waters from the South Pacific travel eastwards and override the cold waters of the Humboldt Current that flows from south to north along the coast of Peru. This produces rains on the normally arid Peruvian coast and droughts in the highlands but also affects the weather in Mexico, the Caribbean, the United States, and even Western Europe. El Niño-induced weather is radically different from normal variations in these areas and usually results in severe impacts to economies and human lives. Knowing when El Niños occurred in the past, their intensities, and frequencies thus are important to help us understand El Niños in general and to learn how to avoid or mitigate their impacts.

Dr. Jeffrey Quilter of Harvard University will direct a small research team to focus on a specific aspect of El Niños on the coast of Peru that will produce important data and information. In the 15th century, ancient Peruvians built earthen aqueducts in their extensive canal systems. These aqueducts cut across the mouths of side canyons in larger valleys, thus creating dams for any water flowing through them during El Niño events. Over time, sediments from El Niño events were built up behind these aqueduct-dams. While el Nino related sediments can be identified in relevant deposits it is not possible to determine rates associated with individual el Nino events. This award will permit measuring devices to be installed in areas behind multiple dams to determine sediment buildup resulting from heavy rainfall predicted to occur during the upcoming el Nino season. These deposits can then be analyzed to better understand earlier strata and the El Niños that deposited them. This work will be done in cooperation with Peruvian authorities who will monitor the events via drone technology as they happen.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research carried out with this National Science Foundation (NSF) grant used archaeology to learn more about a highly significant, recurring climatic event, El Niño, that greatly impacts the United States and many other countries. Technically a component of the El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO), El Niños begin with the movement of large masses of Southern Pacific warm waters eastward where they override the cold Humboldt Current directly offshore of the coast of Peru. This commonly causes heavy rains to fall on the usually arid coast and produces droughts in the Andean highlands.

El Niño events have far-reaching disruptive influences on weather around the world, including the United States, Western Europe, East Africa, South and Southeast Asia, and Australia. They tend to produce the inverse of “normal” conditions, such as rain in dry periods and drought in rainy seasons. Two decades ago, conventional wisdom stated that El Niños occurred about every seven years. Since then, however, we have learned that the frequency of ENSOs and their intensities vary greatly. Sustained patterns, however, are part of long-term world climate changes.

Knowing the history of El Niño and the frequency and intensity of such events in the past can help us to better understand them today and to prepare for future ENSO variability and long-term climate change. Archaeology is an established discipline that can investigate the remote past, beyond historical records to look deep into prehistory. Following previous researchers, we employed methods to chronicle El Niño events in prehistory with particular attention to the period of CE (“AD”) 1000—1450, when a prehistoric culture, the Chimu, built a complex empire on the North Coast of Peru.

When El Niño rains occur, they wash down the sides of small canyons (quebradas) and carry sediments and desert plant fragments with them. These materials are deposited in layers when the waters encounter barriers such as earthen aqueducts or mud-brick (adobe) architecture. We selected seven sections of such a Chimu aqueduct to place small excavations to search for layers of sediments in which we wished to find plant fragments that we could date using the radiocarbon method. Theoretically, we would be able to build a chronology of how many El Niños had occurred during the more than four centuries in which the Chimu culture thrived in the region. We also took advantage of the El Niño event of 2017 to place PVC pipe in the ground at the seven locations to gauge the quantity of sediment deposited against the aqueduct sections that we had selected.

The results of our research were successful insofar as we successfully performed the tasks of investigating flood deposits and the 2017 El Niño. What we discovered, however, was discouraging, because our work undermined our own presumptions and those of many other scholars before us. Although El Niño rains do pond behind prehistoric canals that cut across quebrada mouths and produce graded sediment deposits (rhythmites) reflective of past discharge events caused by El Niños,           there is not a one-to-one relationship between a single El Niño event and a single deposit. Instead, there often are multiple rainfall events during any one El Niño, stretching over months, including dry periods between each rainfall and quite likely producing multiple rhythmites. Indeed, recent research has shown that even in strong ENSO events the frequency, intensity, and even locations of rain over the coast of Peru can vary greatly. 

Our work thus revealed that while the theory of the relationship between sediment deposits and El Niños is sound, our ability to reconstruct prehistoric El Niño frequency will require much more sophisticated and complex methods and greater abilities to identify and date different rhythmites. Thus, although we achieved negative results, we have contributed to the study of ENSOs by learning the limits of current science and have pointed the direction in which to advance such studies in the future.
